confSubmission.title: PAPER AND POSTER TEMPLATE FOR THE MUSIC ENCODING CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS

abstract.head: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: The abstract should consist of a single paragraph containing up to 1200 characters. Only the <rend> and <term> elements are allowed. Other markup is not permitted. The value of <head> for this section must match "ABSTRACT" — no other characters, spaces, or punctuation signs are allowed.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: This template includes information regarding paper and poster markup for the Music Encoding Conference proceedings. It can be downloaded from the Music Encoding Initiative web site (http://music-encoding.org/conference).

You are encouraged to use an XML editor for your submission for the proceedings. There are several available for download. For example, oXygen may be used for free for 30 days under an evaluation license. The use of word-processing software, such as Word, LaTex, etc., is strongly discouraged. If you have limited experience with XML, please contact us for help.
The marked-up paper and all accompanying images should be provided in a .ZIP file containing a single directory.

div.head: MARKUP VS. STYLES
div.p: The goal of this template is uniformity of structure. When the submission's semantic features are indicated instead of its graphical characteristics, consistent formatting can be automatically applied during the production phase via style-sheets.

Therefore, for the most part visual styling should be avoided. When phrase-level styling like bolded or underlined text is required for readability, however, it can be indicated using the <rend> element and an appropriate value for its @rend attribute. For example,

p.egXML: <rend rend="bold">Bold text</rend> <rend rend="underline">Underlined text</rend> <rend rend="italic">Italic text</rend> <rend rend="smcaps">Text in small caps</rend> <rend rend="strike">Struck-through text</rend> text <rend rend="sup">Superscript</rend> text <rend rend="sub">Subscript</rend> <rend rend="fixed-width">Text in a fixed-width font</rend> <rend rend="bold underline italic">Multiple, space-separated values may be used when appropriate.</rend>

div.p: The <term> element may be used to mark descriptive words or phrases of a technical nature, such as the names of XML elements and attributes; class, method, and datatype names; and programming language reserved words. Technical terms will be rendered in a fixed-width font. The use of <term> for these things is preferred over the <rend> element.
URLs that are intended to be actionable must be marked using the <ref> element. For example,

The @target attribute holds the destination URL, but if it is not present, then the content of the <ref> element will be used to create a URL. Therefore, the examples above are equivalent. Submitters are strongly encouraged to test all hyperlinks!
All submitted markup files must be validated against the MEC Proceedings schema. Files that do not validate will be returned to the submitter for correction.

div.head: Title and Authors
div.p: In the final publication the paper/poster title will be presented in all caps.
The lead author’s name should be listed first, followed by any co-authors’ names. Please include an affiliation and email address for each author, even if this results in duplicate addresses.

div.head: Text Length
div.p: Conference papers will be limited to 8 printed pages, while poster presentations will be allowed 2 pages.

div.head: Page Numbering, Headers and Footers, Copyright Notice
div.p: Do not include headers, footers, page numbers, or copyright notice in your submission. These will be added when the proceedings are assembled. The copyright notice will read as follows:

"Permission to make digital or print copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that all copies bear this notice and a full citation on the first page. © [year] Music Encoding Initiative"

div.head: Bibliographic References
div.p: Use <bibl> elements in the text for references to bibliographic items listed in "WORKS CITED". For example, a reference to the journal article cited below can be encoded as:

p.egXML: In his 1921 magnum opus<bibl target="author"/> Artie Author states ...

div.p: The value of the <bibl> element's @target attribute must match the @xml:id of a work in the "Works Cited" section. References to cited works will be labeled automatically.
If a reference is to a specific part of the work, a page or page range for example, then record the specific information within a <biblScope> child of <bibl>. For example,

The point at which the quoted material begins must be captured using the @unit and @from attributes. If the quotation spans multiple units, its terminal point can be captured using the @to attribute. The scope of the citation should not be enclosed in parentheses, brackets, or other symbols — these will be supplied later.

div.head: HEADINGS
div.p: All headings should be captured using the <head> tag inside the div to which they pertain. Styling will be applied based on the nesting level of the heading. First level headings will be displayed as bold, capitalized text.

div.head: Second level headings
div.p: Second level headings will be displayed as bold text.

div.head: Third level headings
div.p: Third level headings will be displayed using italic text. Using more than three levels of headings is highly discouraged.

div.head: Notes
div.p: Indicate notes in the text at the point of attachment; that is, where the note reference (such as a superscript number) would normally appear, using the <annot> element. For example:

p.egXML: This is the sentence to be annotated.The note goes inside the annot element.

div.p: Numbering of the notes is not necessary. Notes will be numbered automatically.
Notes must contain only in-line text and markup, NOT structual markup, such as paragraphs, notes, lists, tables, etc.

div.head: Figures, Tables, Lists, XML Examples, Non-XML Program Code, and Equations
div.p: Figures, tables, XML examples, code listings, and equations do not require a label in the form of "Figure 1.", etc. These features will be automatically and independently numbered. References to these items should be capitalized, for example: "see Figure/Table/Example 1."

div.head: Figures
div.p: All artwork/digital images must be legible, and made available as separate JPEG or PNG files. No art work should be hand-drawn. Lines should be very dark for the purposes of reproduction. Reproductions of the proceedings may not be in color, and therefore all figures and tables must make sense in black-and-white form. The caption element is required even if it has no textual content. Please use it, as demonstrated below, to provide a short, but meaningful description of the figure or table.

Use the element to place figures in the text as close to the reference as possible. The value of the element's @target attribute, like the @src attribute on the tag in HTML, should be the file name of the image to be displayed, including the file type extension. The file name MUST NOT be preceded by any directory path information, for example, "image01.png", not "myFiles/picDirectory/image01.png".

In addition to images, <fig> can contain XML and non-XML code via <egXML> and <programCode> elements, respectively. Locating the example text within <fig> numbers the example within the sequence of figures and provides an opportunity to associate a caption with it. See below for more details on using <egXML> and <programCode>.

p.egXML: <fig> <caption>This code works great!</caption> <programCode> <![CDATA[ Line 1 Line 2 Line 3 ]]​> </programCode> </fig>

div.head: Tables
div.p: This template uses HTML-like table markup. As with figures, a caption is required.

div.head: XML Examples
div.p: Examples of XML encoding (not just MEI) should be marked using the <egXML> element. Please note that the egXML element is in a different namespace. The @xmlns attribute must appear on the <egXML> element.

The XML contained within <egXML> is NOT VALIDATED. However, submitters are encouraged to use the @valid attribute, seen in the example above, to indicate whether the example markup is intended to be correct (true), contains intentional errors (false), or could be made valid by adding certain elements and/or attributes (feasible).

div.head: Non-XML Program Code
div.p: Computer code other than XML must be contained within a <programCode> element containing a CDATA section. The CDATA opening line <![CDATA[ and closing line ]]> must completely enclose the example code. For example:

p.egXML:
<programCode>
  <![CDATA[
  function factorial(n) {
    if (n === 0 || n === 1) {
        return 1;  // 0! = 1! = 1
    }
    return n * factorial(n - 1);
    }
    
    factorial(3); // returns 6
  ]]​>
</programCode>

div.head: Equations
div.p: Markup for equations is similar to that for figures. Equations must be provided as graphical images — MathML and other forms of mathematical markup are not supported.

div.head: QUOTATIONS
div.p: Quotations that flow smoothly from the author's original words into those quoted occur within a paragraph. For example:
div.egXML: Mr. Composer noted that most of the notes in this composition are super melifluous and supercilious.
div.p: Longer quotations appearing as a visually distinct section of the text have a <div> as their parent. For example,
div.egXML:
...

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, eius definitiones ad his, aliquam intellegam mei ex, amet dissentiunt te eos. Cu mea aeque mucius argumentum, mea unum veniam eirmod ea, cu iisque copiosae nominati ius. Quaeque prodesset consetetur quo at, ut magna utamur sensibus sit, mea at partem pericula definiebas. Vix magna summo explicari ea, sea te labore quodsi. Ei nec adhuc interpretaris. No cum laudem inermis nominavi.

...
div.p: Unless the @block attribute indicates otherwise, a quotation appearing as a descendant of a paragraph will be rendered as in-line text, while a quotation occurring within a division of the text will be rendered as a block-level element. Use of quotation marks must be indicated using the <rend> element, as in the in-line quote example above.
A quotation must contain an accompanying <bibl> element.

div.head: CITATIONS
div.p: The final section of the paper must contain all bibliographic citations, in MLA style, and in alphabetical order by (first) author's surname. All cited works should be refered to in the text. Each bibliographic citation should be uniquely labeled using its @xml:id attribute, i.e., <bibl xml:id="builder">. Citations in the "WORKS CITED" section will be numbered automatically. The value of <head> for this section must match "WORKS CITED" — no other characters, spaces, or punctuation signs are allowed.
Citations should be for the complete item; that is, its full extent. A page range is required for a book chapter, encyclopedia entry, journal article, or conference proceedings citation.

For all bibliographic items in "WORKS CITED", use indirect order (Lastname, Firstname) for the first author and direct order (Firstname Lastname) for second and third authors. Use the principle author's name and "et al." when there are more than 3 authors.
Use "Volume.Issue (Year published)" notation for journal articles. The separator for volume and issue information is a period. Publication year for articles should appear in parentheses.
Dissertations and theses must be labeled as either "PhD Dissertation" or "Master's Thesis".
Use an edition statement, e.g. "3rd ed." or "Revised ed.", for any edition of a bibliographic item other than the first.
